transcripts.text: Hey everybody, I'm Joshua.
And I'm Caleb.

And this is Candy Corn.  I know most of you don't like it, but I find it delicious.  Last year around this time, in what I call Candy Corn time, or Halloween, we talked about how there's some really real things out there.  Things like magic, witches, spells, evil, all the stuff we make fun of as not being real.
Yeah.

But that Satan's plot to get that a part of your life is to glitz it up and glamour and bows and ribbons and put it in your kids shows and put it in these movies and make it socially acceptable.  so you don't really know you're being a part of it.  We covered that last time.  Yeah.  But today...
We'd like to talk about witchcraft.  Oh, what was that word I just said?  Witchcraft?
That's not real.

And you may think, oh, I'm not casting spells.  I'm not conjuring spirits of the dead.  Working magic and all this.  Creepy.  Yeah.  But we like to explain to you how, according to the biblical standard, witchcraft has seeped its way into the church.  And we may be functioning in it when we don't really know.  To understand that, yeah, we've got to go to the story of King Saul in the Bible.  He was told by God to wipe out the Amalekites, every man, woman, child, and all their animals.  He doesn't do it.  He keeps the king Agag alive, and he keeps the best tasty animals for himself.
What a terrible name.
Egg, egg.  It is.
I love tasty animals.

Well, God sends the prophet Samuel to Saul, who says in 1 Samuel 15, 23, See, God's making a comparison between two things.  rebellion and witchcraft, stubbornness, which is linked to pride as idolatry.  That's kind of scary.
Everyone's immediately offended, right?  I'm not stubborn.  Stubbornness isn't witchcraft.  You're stubborn witchcraft.  All of you are guilty.  I'm kidding.  We love you.

Go on.  So we'd like to show you how in four simple acts, which are four simple sins of rebellion, of pride, of legalism and control that you're functioning under a spirit of witchcraft.  So let's look at rebellion.  Rebellion is trying to produce illegitimate authority.  that's not your own.  You're placing your own authority over God's.  That was the first sin in Lucifer's heart that caused him to fall from heaven.  And rebellion really equates his sin.
So how do we fix that?  The Bible is really clear.  James 4, 7 says, Guys, it's not that big of a deal.  You're operating a rebellion?  Submit.

And that means your whole life in obedience to God.  So next we have pride.  That's linked to the arrogance and the stubbornness because a prideful man makes idols out of his own opinions.  He's stubborn in that way.  And the Bible says this idolatry, this stubbornness, that's worshiping something.  You're basically worshiping yourself.  You're not worshiping God.

So instead of proving to you this with my own prideful words, I'll go to the Bible, which says in Proverbs 8, 13, to fear the Lord is to hate evil.  I hate pride and arrogance, evil behavior and perverse speech.

So how do you combat that?  You humble yourself before the Lord?  You don't have to build yourself up.  If you humble yourself, God will elevate you.  So the next step we see is legalism.  And you heard us speak about legalism before and how it seeped its way in the church.  And that is trying to produce a standard through works that is not of God to achieve righteousness.  And it's imposing that standard on other people.

Unfortunately, legalism is actually a fear-based outcome.  When you're operating out of legalism, you're trying to control because you're afraid.  if you don't, sin will run rampant.  Fear, however, is the opposite of love, and so we've got a problem there.  But luckily, in Romans 2, 4, it explains how we can actually fix this problem by saying it's the goodness, the kindness of God that leads men to repentance.  You don't have to take a restrictive vice grip on Christians and tell them, be this way, and that's how you get righteous, because it's the goodness of God that's going to compel them to.

And so the final sin in action we like to look at is control.  You know, when you get into fear, you try to control your environment.  You try to control other people.  It could be from jealousy.  It could be from pride.  But control functions in three ways, through intimidation, through manipulation, and through domination.  Well, manipulation, let's see, someone who views himself as weaker to control another person, they try to manipulate them like Jacob in the Bible.  intimidation, someone who views himself as stronger.  They can impose their will on someone through intimidation, make them do what they want to.  But the end result of both of these actions is domination, to control and dominate another person's life.  And we know that's not a God, because He gave us a free will.  God doesn't want to control us.  But Satan seeks to control us and wants us to try to dominate and control other people's lives as well.  And it's really the result of showing that you don't trust God.

And what the opposite, like you said, of control is, is trust.  So in Psalms 9, 10, it says, and those who know your name will put their trust in you.  For you, Lord, have not forsaken those who seek you.  There's absolutely no need to control anything when you trust.

That's right.  The greatest example of witchcraft in the Bible is none other than Queen Jezebel.  We see that she formed idolatry, idolatrous worship to Baal, to Asherah.  She set up against the Lord's prophets and tried to murder them.  She actually did murder tons of the Lord's prophets.  She functioned in that idolatry.  She functioned in that rebellion.  She manipulated her husband Ahab to try to control an entire nation.  And we even see in Revelation, the church of Thyatira, one of the seven churches, the Lord said, that spirit of Jezebel is alive today in your church.  And he also shows in some of the other seven churches that pride, that control, that legalism, that rebellion has seeped its way to some of the other seven churches.

Guys, I'd like to be practical in what I'm asking of you and what we're explaining today.  And the deal is witchcraft has this really fanciful, ethereal name that when you say it, you start picturing all the different things.  all the silly stuff.  But the thing is that the Bible is saying witchcraft is a very applicable thing that is against the nature of God.  So where does this fit in with the life of a believer?  It's very simple.  Who would you have your life mirror?  How would you have your demeanor, your choices mirror?  Would you have it mirror the countenance and the representation of God?  Would you have it his personality?  Or would you have it mirror the personality of the enemy?  Because when you look at witchcraft, you start talking about things like rebellion, stubbornness, control.  All those things are personality traits of the enemy.  But we are the sons and daughters of God, and we're called to mirror the personality traits of the Father.  So make it very simple, guys.  Cut anything out of your life that mirrors the enemy.  Let your life be a reflection of the Father and do so because he has given you his love and your life and put you here for that purpose.
Join us next time.

Candy corn with the chocolate on it is surprisingly good.  It's like somebody took a Tootsie Roll and a Tootsie Roll was like, hi, candy corn, you're pretty fancy.  And it's like, I love you.  Let's get married.  And then they found like a priest who was probably this guy, the pumpkin candy corn log.  I do, I do.  Next thing you know, he got his baby candy corns, the tootsie rolls on them.  It was legal in the eyes of God and everything.  Delicious.
